I am extremely bullish on the midcaps space and I think you cannot get a better time to stock midcaps, said N 
   
   
   Jayakumar, MD, Prime Securities, in an interview with ET Now.Edited excerpts: 


Donald Trump has threatened to slap a mirror tax in India and he has criticised India for high tariffs. Could this situation escalate or are these just tweets coming in?
Sometimes, he gets up on the right side of the bed from our perspective and sometimes he does not. But I think these are passing days. My own assessment is the comment may mean something over a period of time. May be, there is some negotiating somewhere. Frankly, the sectors are too small. The total quantum as estimated is at about $5-odd billion of exports and that too on some tinkering on taxes which have been principally agreed upon, is not there at least from the listed space perspective. Perhaps steel in some sense could be impacted. But right now, I do not think that is the case even from a steel sector perspective. We have got much bigger things to worry than Trump’s tweets.


And those bigger things are elections or is there anything bigger than that?
Well I think elections were something to worry at least till about 8-10 days ago. My own feeling is that the way things have moved, public reactions to whatever has happened notwithstanding whatever has happened, is in terms of how many died etc. The reality is that you had a case of somebody who has landed on enemy camp and comeback. If that is not a victory for diplomacy, what is? We can keep arguing whichever way, but summing substance is we have a very weak neighbour, which of course is a matter of worry. Economically, they have become extremely weak. I am not a political commentator at all and I do not think we are anywhere close to war.

But the way it has been heightened, I think there is a clarity that will come through in elections front as a result of public reactions being so positive. My own assessment is that the markets in some sense already suss out these things a little earlier. A week-10 days ago, when we made a pretty strong bottom for midcaps. Every dip in the market index optically will probably keep testing 10500-10600, but you will have a bounce off that. 

I am not a great index believer because the index composition keeps changing and the broad market is much much lower than these levels. I am extremely bullish on the midcaps space and I think you cannot get a better time to stock midcaps. After four, five years of this government, we are back in an broad market index level of 8000-8500. That is where you are getting a chance to pick up a lot of stocks. 

The market as a whole is very bullish. All the classic signs were there. Flows into mutual funds had tapered off, you had problems in terms of capitulation across the board, leverage in terms of midcap promoters, a lot of big groups in trouble when the stocks were getting busted. These were the classic signs of a capitulation in the midcap space. 

On the frontline space, for almost six months, we were in this 10400 to 11200 range and we pretty much stayed the course. For once, I believe now we are going to get pass the 11200 range. We will make new highs even before the elections on the index front. We will have a huge value pickup on the broad market front.


You are talking about a lot of opportunity. You are very bullish and you have always maintained a stock specific stance. Where can one find value in midcaps?
I do not talk stocks specifically, but if you look sectorally, there are multiple sectors, where some of the frontliners have dropped 70-80% for reasons which have been other than just the fact that business has suffered. 

Pharma offers a greatest opportunity in terms of a big sector play where there are two or three largecap stocks in the generic space. The generic space in the US has made at least a quarter or two quarter go in terms of price and in terms of the business potential, it has made a fantastic bottom. So, there is pricing power, which can only go up. 

Two, business prospects are on the ascendant. Pharma as a largecap space offers great opportunities. From a smallcap perspective, there is a plethora of them. Look at industry leaders in home building, home financing and even in the NBFC space where the stocks have got pummelled 70-80%, Those are well capitalised and they have come off from being 4.5-5 times book premium to 2-2.5 times. There is consolidation across-the-board. There is a great opportunity in the space where NBFCs have merged with banks. 

Recently, there were two or three transactions, Some steel companies, even in this gloom, offers some opportunities and the big ones are down 35%-40% from peak levels. So I think there are opportunities across the board and I for one believe that this is a great time to go back to the drawing board, pick up the balance sheets and pick stocks. Karl Marx said, you have nothing to lose except your chains. I think you have nothing to lose except a fixed deposit rate of interest, if that. This is a time to put on risk and hunt for midcaps.


You believe that there is valuation comfort in the larger pool. I am not talking about the benchmark Bajaj Finserv, Bajaj Finances of the world but within the NBFC pool, where is it that you find that comfort?
HFCs is the category where people find most comfort. The NBFCs that have been in the loan against shares space or otherwise, have been actually a little more hit because of markets. 

Also, this entire business about leverage which promoters have enjoyed, NCDs that they have issued to borrow against. Those have all come under bit of cloud. But sectors that are growing the MSME space still offer a well diversified risk portfolio. There are companies that are in niche spaces like education finance which is actually growing. There are companies in spaces like consumer durables. While the big ones are far too expensive, have still not really corrected. Housing finance has been a congested space but there has been a lot of fallout. A number of names have dropped out and the others are actually picking up the slack. 

But linked to this space is a lot of PSU banks that have been picking up portfolios and therefore the retailisation of the PSU bank portfolios is happening amongst at least the top two-three PSU banks. They will represent portfolio qualities very differently from what they did a year, year and a half ago. 

In the past, we used to accuse them of being corporate focussed, high on NPAs with paralysed balance sheet and not able to move. The same balance sheets now got recapitalised. They have recognised losses. 

The NPA recognition has come off and you got now retail portfolios that they are acquiring. This is a perfect storm and we are still trading at 0.6-0.7 times book. The only question mark on PSU banks is whether there is a reasonable window of a period where they do not need to dilute continuously. They are still capital short and to that extent, there could be dilution. But if you really look at it from an opportunity perspective, the top two-three PSU banks could give you 50% returns from here over the next two years.


Are you comfortable with the way they are stretching SBI buying into Jet, etc?
I do not think SBI has bought into Jet. All that they have done is in the interim, they have taken a position where lenders have exercised their free will to take control and there will be presumably further dilution has happens. When it does, their stake comes off and they will sell and move on in life. 

It is a great proactive step in preventing the collapse like Kingfisher that we had five-six years ago. Now a similar step may have prevented that from happening. You learn from the past but look ahead. From that perspective, Jet has been a great story of how PSU banks have moved in and pretty proactively at that. Hats off to that.


While you have maintained that economic growth is perceptibly slowing, you seem to have a tilt towards the engineering space that is intrinsically linked with the macros. What is really driving the conviction?
Over the last two-three decades, engineering spaces have been ignored in some sense. Capacities have remained broadly the same. People have been operating at 60-70% capacities. So the real economies of scale have not kicked in. A lot of small companies, typically Japanese multinationals operating in India, Swiss multinationals operating in India have very low floats. Therefore they have been off the radar in some senses. 

While the Rupee has weakened now, capacities have not increased in engineering space. The available capacities are now are operating at peak capacities. They are debottlenecking to increase capacities. This is the classic case where EBITDA margins actually will explode, PE margins will go up as their top line moves and I think you could have very good four-five engineering names.

I cannot name stocks, but if you were to hunt deep enough, there are lots of opportunities in multinationals operating in India. We have not been adding capacities and now for the first time we are operating at full capacities in addition to exports coming through, in addition to captive business being there, etc. These are all perfect storms for value creation.


You have said you continue to like chemicals. This is the most misunderstood space because each chemical company is different from the other. What within chemicals interests you? This is a continuing theme. We had the first phase runup where simply people said China is preventing polluting industries to operate and therefore everybody moved. As we have seen, many of these companies have corrected quite dramatically -- whether it is in terms of the industries which are steel-related or chemical industries to be used as an intermediate for pharma. 

Chemical is a loose term, essentially it means polluting industries where the first phase cut down happened. Many of these companies went up and with the market had come off. It is time to relook at those because the absence of polluting industries in China is not a transient theme, it is here to stay. They are going to cut back even more severely and the next wave may well be in terms of a lot of polluting steel-related spaces. 

There could be companies in the solar industry which could be benefitted. So I think chemicals is loose, I agree that that has been a sort of a liberal use of that terminology but the idea here is that the polluting theme has not gone away and I think as you look at greater call on China-US negotiations, one of the big themes that is going to be here to stay is the polluting aspect, their own contribution to the climate change and stuff like that. This is one theme we should pursue.

I also think that in power companies, the resolutions are leading to very interesting acquisitions that people are making. Those who have been in the power and in the infra space and acquiring some of these assets, may actually end up with a very interesting portfolio. A lot of issues facing power companies will get resolved as we go along in the next few months. Linked to that, the typical pre-election and post election themes traversing that area could be the infra and road, where a lot of orders get issued at this point in time. A couple of days ago, there was relaxation in terms of the REIT and InvIT issuances where 49% becomes 70% in terms of portfolio coverage. That would benefit road companies immensely. So, there are a few listed spaces which you could look at.


What about the good old private sector banks and especially now the corporate banks which just about everyone seems to be recommending and autos? Do you think there will be a big sectoral churn?
When I said fresh highs, what I meant was that I think this 11200 that has not been crossed will be taken out. Whether we will cross 11600 I am not sure but I would not be surprised if we saw a new high before the elections itself.

 So the point here about this is that what will make these new highs happen. PSU banks, pharma will be at the forefront. I am sure Reliance will play its role there, no question. In terms of the good old spaces that people have been invested in, ultimately you need mutual funds and large FIIs to hold these and they continue to hold these. 

I do not think they offer great excitement especially if multiples are recommending those. These are best avoided because it is not often that multiple recommends make money. It is going to be a normal sort of thing. The real alpha is going to be generated elsewhere and we have dwelt on multiple spaces.

Prasanth Prabhakaran, Senior President & CEO, YES Securities, believes that there will be a derating of most of NBFCs by rating agencies and analysts. He laid bare the preference for corporate finance banks such as ICICI and Axis. He spoke to ETNow. 


Edited excerpts:


Within large caps, would you say it is going to be more a broad based move or again the move is going to be narrow, the six-seven stocks are performing?

So, we have chosen sectors. Let me not say sectors, it is stocks that we like in this space. We continue to like the corporate finance ones, which are your ICICI and Axis, and the preference is given to Axis because of the focus towards growth rather than sustenance that ICICI is trying. they are basically trying to maintain and not falter too much whereas Axis has decided to put growth path on their radar. 

Then you have L&T as a pick in the same space, thanks to also the infra spending that has happened and the fact that their businesses are more broad based and their credit cycles have become shorter. It is a more lucrative business. They have cut margins, but they have made sure the cycles are shorter which is core of the business that they have functioned with. Lastly, in the space that is there, it is a momentum move that has continued in the steel sector and so we are bullish on JSW Steel in that space. 

We have stuck to the largecaps, but specific ones. I do not think it is sector wise that we have gone ahead with. There is only one midcap that we have in our pick at this point of time and that is Birla Corp and that too because of the fact that they are central India focussed and they have a lot of infra projects that have come in out there. That is more or less the basket we have gone ahead with.



Let us take a look also in terms of what we are seeing in the IT pack and a lot of strength that seems to be building out there. What is your take on that in terms of the potential going forward, whether or not it is a defensive play or there is genuinely scope here to see more room for growth as well?

In the IT sector, you have two picks that we have when we continue to have over the last quarter or so, which has given results for most of our clients. It remains TCS in the large cap space that we have taken and Persistent in the midcap space, both because of the futuristic move they have made towards products. Because that is where the margins are going to lie, that is where demand lies, that is where you are going to make sure the differentiation between you and the next player. 

You stick to these sectors because of the simple fact that it is not a three-month or a six-month view. This is a good two-year view. They have managed to transform themselves at TCS. They had hardly around 4-5 per cent of their top line coming in from their businesses which were apart from services. 

Around 23-25% of their top line now comes in from their product businesses and allied businesses, the digital business that they have talked about. So interesting stories to play out and it will continue to hold good for some more time.


I understand you are suggesting to buy corporate banks and the mess through which NBFCs have gone. The one beneficiary pocket of this mess has been corporate banks because that is where more lending would start because NBFCs are dealing through their problems. Going through your note, you are saying liquidity issues in NBFCs will get better now. I understand you have hands-on experience of functioning of NBFCs. Just for our viewers, please explain what is happening in the NBFC space at this point when it comes to liquidity and also if you feel that liquidity pressure is going to ease. Which are those NBFCs and let us not get into consumer NBFCs like Bajaj Finance and Bajaj Finserv of the world? Which are the NBFCs which would capitalise on this liquidity enhancement which would happen in the near future?


What clients need to understand is that the last two quarters have gone by post around September when the crisis actually started off. Most of the NBFCs were lending for a long term, but they had been borrowing for short term because they get cheaper rates to borrow either from a bank or a mutual fund or by CPs that they had issued or by way of NCDs. 

So you have a six-year book, 10-year book based on whether it is a housing loan that you have given or whether it is a car loan or some other short term loan. 

So how do you start lending again, how do you build a book, how do you comeback into growth, those are the concerns that NBFCs have which will continue over the next one odd quarter. By the time the situation will ease off, there is no default and there will be confidence which will come back into the money markets and there will be lending which will start again to this sector. 

It is a crucial segment, it is practically around 30-35 per cent of the retail lending space which is catered to by these players. So it is a crucial area, it needs to be watched. 

Actually one of the NBFCs we have is CanFin Homes. It is a pure retail lending play in the NBFC space. It is among the very few that we have chosen apart from obviously the large ones like HDFC Ltd. because of the pedigree and the way they have been able to manage raising funds and deploying it also.

Does the move so far and especially the kind of broader market recovery that we have seen of late, does it look deceiving and do you think it is going to falter soon or is it looking a little bit more convincing this time?

So the good portion is that it has given a lot of relief to a lot of HNIs which have been beaten black and blue as far as midcaps and smallcaps are concerned. There is a lot of relief on that side. But it is a little too premature. 

There are still events that are supposed to flow out in the next quarter or so, which includes the elections, liquidity push and as far as NBFC is concerned, they have still not seen an end to it and lastly the pickup of economy which is the last portion of it. In this, elections seems to be moving towards a consensus and that will firm up the moment your election season is over. 

As far as liquidity is concerned, the NBFCs that we have spoken to have managed to tide over the short-term crisis. Now the growth will happen, but there will be a derating of most of NBFCs by the rating agencies and analysts. So you will have some pain there. My belief is that you are in the top end of the spectrum as far as valuations are concerned. 

You will again see a range between 10,400 and 11,100-11,200. In that range, your markets will ease off and it will start picking up from the bottom post the Q1 getting over anywhere. It is around that period that we will expect the markets to start taking off and you should build up a portfolio for the long term in the midcap space. The next quarter is a largecap space that I will stick to because midcaps have run up way ahead of their fundamentals at this point.

The market tends to downsize the valuations of large conglomerates, as it is difficult to analyse them. Parent companies, therefore, often quote at a discount to their intrinsic values. “It is easy to analyse standalone companies. A number of businesses makes analysis quite difficult. Since the risk is higher, the market gives only lower valuation,” says Shailendra Kumar, CIO, Narnolia Financial Advisors.

Also, with holding companies, investors are forced to buy several businesses, all of which may not be their favourite, and this also leads to lower valuations. Another reason is that most Indian holding companies are investment companies of their promoters, and their actions may often be in the interest of the promoters and not of the minority shareholders. Finally, the valuation differentials across countries also contribute to the parent company discount. For instance, Maruti Suzuki is now quoting at a premium to its Japanese parent, Suzuki Motor Corp.


Sound investment bets
As discounts of some holding companies have recently increased, they have become quite promising. “About 30%-40% holding company discounts are common in India and, therefore, go with companies with larger discounts,” says Daljeet S. Kohli, Fund Manager, Valentis Advisors.

But you need to be careful of intergroup transfers that may favour promoters and not the retail investors. For instance, the recent decision of Cairn India Holding—a subsidiary of Vedanta—to pay Rs 1,430 crore to Volcan Investments—the parent company of Vedanta—to invest in Anglo American, held by Volcan, has raised concerns. You should also avoid parent companies that are quoting at a discount because of poor corporate governance. Also, you need to stay invested for the long term, as it can take time before a parent company decides to unlock the value in the subsidiary companies.

After taking all of the above into consideration, the following holding companies seem ripe for investment*.


1. Bajaj Holdings: Robust growth of subsidiaries
Total value of holdings: Rs 68,215 crore
Market-cap of Bajaj Holdings: Rs 35,270 crore
Discount: 48% 

 Bajaj Holdings has several fast growing companies under its umbrella. It has direct investment in Bajaj Auto, and holdings in Bajaj Finance, Bajaj Allianz General Insurance and Bajaj Allianz Life Insurance through Bajaj Finserv. “Consumer durables finance penetration is only around 20% and Bajaj Finance has around 70% market share. Despite strong growth in past five years, Bajaj Finance’s loan book should grow at 32% CAGR over 2018-19 to 2020-21,” says a recent Jefferies India report. It’s unlisted subsidiaries, Bajaj Allianz General Insurance and Bajaj Allianz Life Insurance, are also doing well. Given the performance of all its subsidiaries, the 48% discount to net asset value (NAV) is not justified.


2. Godrej Industries: Holds promising unlisted firms
Total value of holdings: Rs 30,644 crore
Market-cap of Godrej Inds: Rs 16,868 crore
Discount: 45% 

 After the listing of Godrej Agrovet, Godrej Industries has almost became a holding company because it generates major value from its listed subsidiaries and associate companies. However, the business of the parent company, which mostly deals in chemicals now, is not negligible—it generated revenue and net profit of Rs 573 crore and Rs 50 crore, respectively, during the third quarter of 2018-19. As it has several unlisted subsidiaries with 100% holdings, the actual discount is much more than the 45% computed on the basis of its listed subsidiaries.


3. Grasim Holdings: Parent sees sharp growth
Total value of holdings: Rs 84,823 crore
Market-cap of Godrej Inds: Rs 53,131 crore
Discount: 37% 

 Since the domestic demand for VSF—a biodegradable fibre— continues to be robust, the standalone business of Grasim is also doing well. While its revenue for the third quarter of 2018-19 grew 21% year-on-year (y-o-y), to Rs 5,293 crore, its net profit grew 28%, y-o-y, to Rs 608 crore. The outlook for its standalone business remains robust. While its discount based on listed subsidiaries is placed only at 37%, this does not consider its booming standalone business. Even at a PE of eight, based on its last year’s standalone net profit, this division should be valued at Rs 14,000 crore, which will take the discount to 46%. While most of its subsidiaries are also doing well, there is concern about its loss-making telecom subsidiary—Idea. However, Grasim’s Idea holding came down to 11.55%, after the telco’s recent merger with Vodafone.



*Market-cap as on 5 Mar 2019. Holdings as on 31 Dec 2018. Compiled By ETIG Database

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 9.50 points, or 0.08 per cent, lower at 11,322.50, indicating a flat-to-negative start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks which may buzz the most in today’s trade: 


State Bank of India (SBI): The largest state-run bank has put on sale six NPA accounts worth Rs 2,337.88 crore, which will be auctioned on March 26. 


HDFC Life Insurance: The two-day offer for sale (OFS) by HDFC Life Insurance Company saw a strong response from non-retail investors on Tuesday, as the issue was subscribed 2.60 times of the base issue size and 1.83 times of the total issue on first day. 


Vedanta: British oil firm Cairn Energy on Tuesday said its holding in Vedanta has dropped to just 0.1 per cent after the Income Tax Department sold most of its 4.9 per cent stake in the company to recover a retrospective tax demand.


RCom: National Company Law Appellate Tribunal on Tuesday warned Reliance Communications' (RCom) lenders that their failure to release tax refunds to clear the telco's dues may force the court to send the operator back into insolvency proceedings. 


Cadila Healthcare: The drug maker said it has received final approval from the US health regulator to market Atenolol and Chlorthalidone tablets USP, used to treat high blood pressure, in the US.


Kotak Mahindra Bank: The Bombay High Court declined a suggestion by Kotak Mahindra Bank promoters to cap their voting rights at 20 per cent of the total shareholding even when their holding is higher at 30 per cent with an aim to comply with the regulatory intent.


Bandhan Bank: The bank’s proposed 14.9 per cent stake allotment to HDFC for merging Gruh Finance will test the Reserve Bank of India's regulations of 2016 on shareholding in private sector banks.


Bharti Infratel: An arbitral tribunal has dismissed Bharti Infratel’s exit charges claim of over Rs 195 crore (including multiple interest levies) from Sistema Shyam Teleservices (SSTL), saying the Indian arm of Russia’s Sistema JSFC is not liable to pay for premature termination of service contracts.


GMR Infa: Sidharath Kapur, executive director and the main brain behind GMR Infra’s expansive airports business, has resigned, said two people aware of the matter.


Mahindra CIE: Auto component firm Mahindra CIE Automotive said its board has approved to buy Aurangabad Electricals (AEL) for Rs 875.6 crore. 


Axis Bank: The lender has appointed Rakesh Makhija as its non-executive chairman for a term of three years, with effect from July 18.


Bank of Maharashtra: The state-owned bank has put on sale movable and immovable properties of Unity Appliances, a unit of debtridden Videocon Group, to recover Rs 153.8 crore loan. 


Jet Airways: Even as speculations are rife that Etihad Airways has set several conditions to extend a financial lifeline to save Jet Airways, Jet said that four more aircraft have been grounded over non-repayment of dues to lessors, taking the total to 32.


CPSE stocks: The government is considering launching a public offer of the CPSE ETF in March itself to mobilise Rs 3,500 crore with a green shoe option of up to ₹10,000 crore. This will be the fifth issue of CPSE ETF. 


IPO WATCH
MSTC: The IPO by miniratna will hit the primary market on Wednesday. The government proposes to offload 1.76 crore shares or 25 per cent of total paid-up equity of the largest B2B e-commerce company in India. The issue by the Kolkata-headquartered firm will close on March 15.


Board meetings
 

Analyst calls•IIFL has an add rating on Godrej Consumer Products with a target price of ₹750. Godrej Consumer has fallen short of its ambitious sales target over the past decade, but has transformed itself to become a professionally run business across three continents and several product categories, said IIFL.

• Ambit Capital has initiated coverage on Page Industries with a sell rating and target price of Rs 20,000. Recent growth slowdown is caused by disruption (GST-related), discontent in wholesale channel, rising competition from Van Heusen and Jockey’s weakness in female innerwear, said Ambit.

• Kotak Institutional Equities has an add rating on Bajaj Consumer Care with a fair value of Rs 405. The company needs to find material success outside its core almond drops hair oil portfolio for the stock to rerate, the brokerage said. 

• Reliance Securities had maintained buy rating on J Kumar Infraprojects with a revised target price of ₹260. The brokerage has retained positive view on J Kumar Infraprojects owing to robust order book, sound execution credentials, consistent focus on high-margin projects in limited geographies, asset light business model and superior management bandwidth. 

• YES Securities has initiated coverage on Capacite Infraprojects with a target price of ₹330. In a very short span, Capacite Infraprojects has carved a niche in the building EPC segment with an unexecuted order book of Rs 75 billion and this figure excludes the Rs 43.6 billion order won from MHADA and L1 position in public sector worth Rs 4.6 billion.

New Delhi: Bajaj Finserv Wednesday said its Chairman and Non-Executive Director Rahul Bajaj has resigned and will take over as the Chairman Emeritus from May.

Bajaj, 80, vide a letter dated February 15, 2019, has tendered his resignation which will be effective from the conclusion of the board meeting scheduled for May 16, 2019, the company said in a regulatory filing.

His appointment as Chairman Emeritus will be effective from May 16, 2019, it added.

"The board of directors has appointed Nanoo Pamnani as Independent Non-Executive Chairman of the company in place of Rahul Bajaj, with effect from May 17, 2019," it said.

The company has also approved reappointment of independent directors D J Balaji Rao, Nanoo Pamnani and Gita Piramal for a second term of five years.

While the appointment of Rao and Pamnani will be with effect from April 1, 2019, Piramal's term will begin from July 16, 2019.

These changes are subject to approval of the shareholders.

Bajaj Finserv deals with financial services of Bajaj Group. Its core businesses are spread across lending, insurance and wealth advisory.

Rahul Bajaj, born on June 1, 1938 is recognised as one of the most successful business leaders of India.

He holds a degree in economics from Delhi University, a degree of law from Bombay University and an MBA from Harvard Business School.

Bajaj heads the Bajaj group of companies apart from being the chairman of the board of many companies.

He was elected to the Upper House of Parliament for 2006-2010 period.

Stock of Bajaj Finserv closed 1.22 per cent higher at Rs 6,920 on BSE.

IIM Shillong has concluded final placements for its 10th batch of 177 students, with the highest package of Rs 28 lakh and average package of Rs 16.79 lakh, a jump of 8.3% from last year. The top 20% and top 50% of the batch secured an average package of Rs 22.67 lakh and Rs 19.75 lakh respectively, while the median package jumped to Rs 16.5 lakh.

The final placement season saw participation from 62 recruiters. Consulting & strategy became the most sought-after domain this year, with 26.5% of the total offers made to the participants.

Several prominent recruiters made offers including Accenture, Amazon, Cognizant, Deloitte USI, GroupM, ICICI Bank, Infosys, JP Morgan & Chase, Nomura Investment Bank, Northern Arc, RBL Bank, ShopClues, Stellium Consulting, TATA Motors, TATA Steel, Ujjivan Small Finance Bank, ValueLabs and VMWare. The institute also hosted many first-time recruiters including Bain Capability Network, Bajaj Finserv, Basix Sub-K, Carwale, eClerx, EY, Essar Group, Freudenberg, GMM Pfaudler, HDFC Bank, Henkel, Landmark Group (Splash), Markets & Markets, Maruti Suzuki, Ola Cabs, OYO, TAFE, TATA Power, Tredence, TresVista, Trident, Ultratech Cement, UnitedHealth Group, Vedanta and Xiaomi.

The PGP 2017-19 batch also bagged PPI/PPO opportunities from Aditya Birla Group, Amazon, Barclays, Berger Paints, Deloitte USI, Fidelity Investments, ICICI Bank, ITC, Mahindra GMC, Muthoot Group, Nomura Investment Bank, Piramal, Reliance Industries, Rivigo, TATA Motors, TATA Steel, Titan, Wipro and Yes Bank.

Consulting & Strategy emerged as the highest paying domain, with the average CTC of Rs 17.96 lakh. Students have been offered several roles ranging across advisory, analytics, change management, consulting, corporate strategy, investment banking, retail management, sales & marketing, strategy & operations and supply chain management.

Cognizant, Deloitte USI, ICICI Bank, JP Morgan & Chase and TATA Steel made the maximum number of offers this year.

NEW DELHI: Strong gains in banking, financial and IT stocks gave a fillip to the Indian equity market on Thursday as positive signals from the ongoing US-China trade talks fuelled investor risk appetite.

Reports that China has made some unprecedented proposals in trade talks with the US to overcome the remaining obstacles to a deal lifted investor confidence. Moreover, unabated FPI flows kept the sentiment high. Data suggests FPIs have pumped Rs 29,089 crore into domestic equities so far in March. 

Sensex surged 413 points, or 1.08 per cent, to close at 38,545, with 23 stocks ending in the green, seven in the red. One remained unchanged. Nifty jumped 125 points, or 1.09 per cent, to 11,570, with 37 stocks up and 13 down.

BSE Midcap and Smallcap indices closed higher by 1.06 per cent and 0.95 per cent, respectively. 


Here’s a look at the highlights of Thursday's session:

Infosys buys 75% in ABN AMRO BankThe IT major said it would acquire a 75 per cent stake in Stater NV, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Netherlands’ third largest lender ABN AMRO. The acquisition, the company said, would boost operational efficiencies and enhance its strategy to help clients navigate their digital transformation. The stock settled 1.30 per cent higher at Rs 738. 


DHFL shares surge 10%Shares of Dewan Housing Finance Corporation (DHFL) closed 9.53 per cent higher at Rs 149.40 after media reports suggested that Piramal Enterprises and Baring Private Equity (PE) are in talks to acquire a majority stake in the company. 


BoB jumps on govt capital infusionShares of Bank of Baroda (BoB) closed 6.62 per cent higher at Rs 129.60 after the government said it would infuse Rs 5,042 crore in the bank ahead of its merger of Dena Bank and Vijaya Bank on April 1. Separately, an ET report suggested that the bank is set to raise up to $1 billion by selling bonds overseas to solidify its capital position. 


Sheela Foam OFS subscribed 5.23 timesThe offer for sale (OFS) by Sheela Foam received strong response from retail investors and was subscribed 5.23 times on Day 2. The issue received retail bids for 27,26,373 shares, which was 5.23 times the total size of 5,20,942 shares. The portion for the retail category was fixed at 10 per cent.


Titan's m-cap tops Rs 1 lakh cr markThe market capitalisation of Titan jumped to Rs 1,00,674.95 crore as the stock touched its all-time high of Rs 1,135. It closed the day 1.77 per cent higher at Rs 1,134.


Rs 1.52 lakh cr wealth created in a dayThursday's market rally made investors richer by Rs 1.52 lakh crore as the overall market-capitalisation of BSE-listed firms jumped to Rs 1,49,83,159.64 crore from Rs 1,48,30,498.41 crore a day earlier. 


PFC completes REC buyState-owned Power Finance Corporation completed the acquisition of majority stake in REC by paying Rs 14,500 crore to the government, PTI reported. The transaction will help the government meet its disinvestment target of Rs 80,000 crore for this financial year. Shares of PFC closed 0.13 per cent down at Rs 117.55, while those of REC closed flat at Rs 149.30.


84 stocks show potential to riseMomentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bullish crossovers on 84 counters on BSE, indicating that these stocks may see upsides in the coming sessions. Among the stocks that showed bullish crossovers were Delta Corp, Oil India, ICICI Prudential Life Insurance, Phillips Carbon Black, United Bank of India and Indian Bank. On the other hand, 74 stocks, including Tata Power, Exide Industries, HPCL, Reliance Naval, Aster DM Healthcare, Bajaj Finserv, Britannia Industries and SRF, saw bearish crossovers. 


UCO Bank, Indian Bank above 200 DMAsUnited Bank, UCO Bank, Radico Khaitan, Panacea Biotec, Indian Bank and Weizmann Forex were among the stocks that traded above their 200 DMAs. On the flip side, Mindtree, Jet Airways, ONGC, Ashoka Buildcon, Raymond and Welspun India were among the stocks that traded below their 200 DMAs.

Ashish Chaturmohta 
HEad-technical & Derivatives, Sanctum Wealth Management

Where are We? Market finished the final trading day of the financial year on a positive note to close at 11,623.9 with a gain of 0.47 per cent for the day and 1.46 per cent on a weekly basis. For FY19, Nifty has seen gains of 14.93 per cent. Broader market indices — BSE Midcap and Smallcap — gained 2.67 per cent and 1.86 per cent, respectively, for the week outperforming the benchmark indices. The market breadth on NSE was positive with 5 stocks advancing for every 4 declines.


What is in Store? Nifty has formed long body bullish candlestick on weekly and monthly charts. Strong momentum suggests the market is going ahead towards its all-time high of 11,760. Immediate support of 11,550 is needed for the last week’s rally to continue towards new highs. Crossing and sustaining above 11,760 on tradable basis. Next level for Nifty is seen at 11,830 and 11,900. On the downside, last week’s low of 11,311 becomes critical for the market. A decline below would break the sequence of higher highs and higher lows. In Nifty options, maximum open interest for puts is at 11,500 strike, followed by 11,000. For calls, it is seen at strike price of 12,000 and 11,600. Put writing was seen in 11,500 and 11,600 along with call writing in 12,000 and 11,700.


What could Investors Do? India VIX surged 5.6 per cent for the week to close at 17.2. In last three weeks, volatility has seen a rise from 15 levels. VIX needs to settle at the current level or decrease for the rally to continue, otherwise further increase may stall the rally. Stock specific, Bajaj Finserv, Petronet LNG, Asian Paints, IDBI Bank and NBCC have witnessed consolidation and showing breakouts.

NEW DELHI: Most agri sector stocks were trading with losses in Wednesday's session after private weather forecasting agency Skymet said that monsoon rains in India are expected to be below normal this year dampening prospects of higher farm and economic growth. 

According to Skymet Weather, monsoon in 2019 was likely to be ‘below normal’ to the tune of 93 per cent of the long period average (LPA) of 887 mm for the fourthmonth period from June to September. 

Companies such as Jain Irrigation, Escorts, PI Industries pared gains and were trading down up to 3 per cent in the afternoon trade. Skymet sees below normal monsoon due to climate change and carbon emissions. 

AgriTech (India) (down 4.42 per cent), Proseed India (down 4.35 per cent), Indo Us (down 3.32 per cent), Jain Irrigation Systems (down 3.11 per cent), Avanti Feeds (down 2.71 per cent), Camson Bio Technologies (down 2.26 per cent) and Chamanlal Setia Exports (down 2.14 per cent) declined up to 5 per cent. 

Simran Farms (down 1.84 per cent), Kohinoor Foods (down 1.77 per cent) and KRBL (down 1.60 per cent) also declined significantly. 

Meanwhile, shares of Ocean Agro (India) (up 4.90 per cent), MISHTANN (up 1.97 per cent), Trescon (up 1.70 per cent), Freshtrop Fruits (up 1.21 per cent) and Kaveri Seed Company (up 0.89 per cent) were trading with gains. 

The NSE Nifty50 index was trading 5.70 points down at 11,707.50 while the 30share BSE Sensex was up 27.29 points at 39,083.94 at around 02:39 pm. 

Indiabulls Housing Finance (up 3.95 per cent), Maruti Suzuki India (up 2.21 per cent), Bajaj Finserv (up 1.80 per cent), JSW Steel (up 1.62 per cent), HCL Technologies (up 1.55 per cent) and Tata Steel (up 1.35 per cent) were among the top gainers in the Nifty pack. 

On the other hand, Hindustan Petroleum Corporation (down 4.09 per cent), Bharat Petroleum Corporation (down 4.06 per cent), Indian Oil Corporation (down 2.12 per cent) and Zee Entertainment Enterprises (down 2.03 per cent) were trading in the red.

By Chandan Taparia 
The Nifty50 hit a new lifetime high of 11,761 on Wednesday, but failed to hold its gains ahead of RBI’s money policy and witnessed sharp decline towards 11,630 level amid profit booking. The index formed a Bearish Engulfing pattern followed by two Doji candles on the daily scale and also negated the formation of higher lows of last six sessions by slipping below the previous day’s low of 11,655.

Overall, the medium-term trend of the market is positive, but a pause in the positive momentum with negative divergence in the RSI indicators suggests some consolidation is required for a decisive move beyond its lifetime high of 11,761. It has immediate support near the 11,550 mark while hurdles are placed at 11,760 level. A decisive range breakout is required for the next leg of rally.

India VIX moved up 3.89 per cent to 18.78. VIX started to hold at higher levels. It needs to cool off to shift its base to higher levels, else volatile swing could start in the market.

On the Options front, maximum Put open interest was at 11,000 followed by 11,500 levels, while maximum Call OI was at 12,000 followed by 11,800. There was Call writing at 11,900 followed by 12,000 levels while Put writing was seen at 11,500 followed by 11,700. The option band signified a broader trading range between 11,500 and 11,800 levels.

Bank Nifty got stuck in a range since last five sessions and failed to hold above the 30,500-30,650 zone. It witnessed a decline towards 30,000 level amid profit booking and formed a bearish candle on the daily scale, which suggests the immediate support zone is being tested. Now Bank Nifty has to respect the immediate support at 29,888 to again attract buying interest towards 30,250 and then 30,500 levels while next major support is seen at 29,750 level.

Nifty futures closed negative at 11,724 level with a loss of 0.47 per cent. Long buildup was seen in Marico, Bajaj Finserv, OFSS and Pidilite Industries while shorts were seen in Amara Raja Batteries, BPCL, Dish TV and HPCL.

(Chandan Taparia is Technical & Derivative Analyst at MOFSL. Investors are advised to consult financial advisers before taking an investment calls based on these observations)

India needs stronger NBFCs to take financial inclusion forward, says Sanjiv Bajaj, MD and CEO, Bajaj Finserv. In an interview with ETNow, he said his company is in a superior position because of the value proposition it brings to the table. Edited excerpts:


What are your readings of the financial landscape in India?

There are multiple issues over here and that is why this is not an easy answer. I think as far as Indiabulls is concerned, they are in a peculiar situation and maybe this is a solution for them if they get RBI approval. I do not know too much detail other than what one reads in the papers. 

There is an equally strong opportunity in this country whether you are a bank or you are an NBFC, and that is something we as Bajaj Finance have demonstrated over the last 10-11 years that you do not need a bank licence to do 70 per cent of what a bank does and yes, you cannot do 30 per cent. 

This country is so large, it is so deeply unpenetrated if that is the right English as far as financial services concerned. So, we have a lot to do and we have been able to show that. I believe that there are too many limitations around the banking licence which will interest good long-term promoters to apply. 

For example, it is silly to have a rule to say you have to come down to 15 per cent ownership. Why? If we are building something of high quality, if I can today manage Rs 70,000 crore of insurance policy holders money for the long term, what is difference if that customer is a banking customer? 

Insurance industry has shown since 2001 that it can be trusted and we have to get away from the old ways of thinking that no businessman can be trusted to trusting the ones who have proven themselves and allowing them to build within a certain set of regulatory limitations businesses. 

Are you therefore saying you may not be interested in applying for a banking licence or going down the M&A route for a bank unless you see the rules of the game change, unless for example the Reserve Bank relooks at promoter ownership issue?

All I can say at this point is we are not looking at it.


But do you think this is a healthy sign...?

It's difficult to answer that without understanding the details of the situation. As I said, this a particular situation and if that is the right answer for them as long as it meets RBI’s requirements and shareholder approval, that is their call to make. But clearly, this country needs many more banks and many stronger NBFCs if we have to really take financial penetration to the masses.


When the government changed rules for FDI, there was all this talk of how the gates were going to open the floodgates. We did not really see that happen. And there was a lot of talk whether your joint venture would stand or whether we would see the put-call option. It did not happen. Is anything on the cards?

Nothing is on the cards. When the government was opening this, we told them as well that do not expect that because a lot of the large insurance companies were already adequately capitalised and they were making a reasonable amount of money. So, they did not need the additional capital. 

The additional capital was only if the foreign promoter wanted to take their stake up and we have seen that in a few companies. You had to also keep in mind that the last 4-5 years when this happened has been a very volatile period globally and it depends on the priorities of the foreign promoter. India fits into most of their long-term priorities.

It very much does so for Allianz from what I know, but they are very comfortable with the way the businesses are being run right now. The businesses are profitable. They do not need to put in more capital into the company. Neither of us has done that for almost 10 years now and they are happy to use that capital elsewhere where they need to grow further.


They are going to stay where they are, is this what you are basically saying?

At this point, yes till they come back to us with some...


You have a sense of the consumption story and how the economy is performing. Is it really as good as the incumbent government tells us or is it as bad as the Opposition tells us?

We see some trends on the consumer side that does not necessarily mean it is the only proxy for how the economy is doing. But for us, the closest big day was Gudi Padwa which just got over, especially in Maharashtra, which is the new year there. 

And we saw different growth curbs. Urban India did grow for us, but growth was slower. 

Tier II to tier IV towns were growing at twice the rate and I think this is something that we are seeing consistently over the last year or two. Just with greater wealth creation and availability of financial services, aspirations are growing, whether you are in tier IV or tier I. 

Maybe, your pocket is a little smaller. We are seeing these aspirations driving consumption and we are seeing it very strong in outside say the top 70-80 cities.


How do I juxtapose that with other indicators that are coming in, for example auto sales? The auto companies cannot understand why sales are not taking off at all that will have a domino impact on a company like yours. 

It should have. It should have a domino impact on the industry. As a company, we are slightly in a superior position because of the value proposition we are able to do with our instant loans, with our small ticket insurance which gives us the additional volume. 

But yes to the larger industry, it should be. The larger industry has not shown very strong credit growth if you look at the banking industry. If you look at general insurance on the other hand, the industry has grown at about 13-14 per cent, but we have grown almost at twice that rate. So, it varies. We are not necessarily the right proxy for the industry, at least these recent years because we have been able to outperform.


If I just look at housing, that has not taken off. Since politics is the flavour of the season, allow me to say this, housing in the last five years of the Modi government has not taken off the way it was supposed to. They have tried a lot of sops, it has not taken off. That also has an impact on a company like yours and the economy.
Housing to me is a very large opportunity for a very long period, at least from a housing finance point of view. This is even for those that are actually building houses across all price points from affordable to at least four bedrooms which would be for the upper middle class and even the rich. 

The really high end one is limited by definition. If you see what has happened in the last 4-5 years, we have not seen rates go down dramatically. But what we have seen is a whole bunch of enactments come in on housing, especially RERA. 

RERA has been very welcome. States that have fully enacted -- and I believe Maharashtra is one of the leading states -- are already seeing benefit of that. But these things take time to play out. Housing is a long-term game. 


But there are a lot of issues in housing too. The RBI governor is also hoping to address them. He has talked about a committee at the last press conference. As an important industry stakeholder, how do you react to that and what is the kind of clean-up that is needed?

The simple thing is that if I am going to give a loan for 10-15 years for housing, I need to borrow for 10-15 years to prevent asset-liability mismatch. Today, there are not too many people who can lend 10-15-year money. One of the very few industries that have long-term money is insurance and pension. 

As an insurance manufacturer, 50 per cent of my investments have to be in government securities. Here, I am giving money to the government in a non-competitive manner. How do I build the sector? A lot of these broader rules have to be corrected which will automatically improve I would say the foundation for housing finance companies. 

Most housing finance companies do not want a high mismatch between the asset and liabilities but they have no choice and you cannot do a 3-year housing loan.

Overall, 25 shares were trading in the green while 24 were trading in the red. 

In the Nifty 50 index, GAIL, Cipla, Asian Paints, Adani Ports SEZ and UltraTech Cement were among the top gainers.

While UPL, Indiabulls Housing Finance, Hindalco Inds., Larsen & Toubro and Bharti Airtel were trading in the red.

It's a question of three Es -- economy, earnings and elections, not necessarily in the same order.

The heat is showing on Indian stocks as the market posted first weekly fall in eight. This followed the IMF lowering India’s growth estimate for 2018-19 and the next two years as well. 

Though corporate earnings for the March quarter kicked off on a strong note on Friday, thanks to TCS and Infosys, investors are wondering what lies ahead.

General elections, which got under way on Thursday and run till May 19, is adding to this level of uncertainties though a win for Prime Minister Narendra Modi is largely being priced in.

Despite all these unknowns, some buying over the last two days of the week kept the downside in the market to a minimum. 

The BSE Sensex slipped 95 points, or 0.24 per cent, to 38,767 on April 12, from 38,862 on April 5. Likewise, the NSE Nifty came off 23 points, or 0.19 per cent, to 11,643 during the same period.

The next week will be a truncated one as the market is shut on Wednesday and Friday for Mahavir Jayanti and Good Friday, respectively. 

Among key data points, WPI inflation for March is slated for Monday. On the global front, Chinese GDP and industrial production data due on Wednesday, along with Opec Meeting, will inject a sense of caution.

Below is a list of top stocks and sectors that made news through the whole week.


Stocks that rallied up to 30%
As many as nine stocks on the BSE500 index managed to deliver over 10 per cent returns to investors during the week gone by. The list featured stocks such as Rain Industries (up 30.85 per cent), PC Jeweller (28.68 per cent), Indiabulls Real Estate (22.92 per cent), Shankara Building Products (16.66 per cent) and Jai Corp (15.20 per cent). 


Pain for 3 scrips Just three stocks such as Century Plyboards (down 11.53 per cent), PNB Housing Finance (down 11.86 per cent) and Reliance Communications (down 22 per cent) on the BSE500 plunged in double digits. 


IPO update
The initial public offering (IPO) of wires and cables manufacturer Polycab India, which was open for subscription from April 5-9, got subscribed over 51.96 times during the week. The Rs 1,345-crore IPO received bids for over 91 crore shares against the total issue size of more than 1.76 crore. 


Lacklustre debut
Shares of Rail Vikas Nigam Limited made a flat market debut on Thursday, listing at its issue price of Rs 19 on BSE and NSE both. The scrip settled 3.94 per cent up at Rs 19.80 on the NSE.


Q4 off to good start
IT majors TCS and Infosys beat Street expectations on Friday with some solid March quarterly numbers. The results came in after market closing. 

While TCS earnings grew 17.7 per cent in January-March from a year earlier, Infosys posted a 10.5 per cent growth in consolidated net profit at Rs 4,078 crore. TCS stock settled 0.26 per cent down at Rs 2,013.75 ahead of earnings whereas Infosys gained 0.63 per cent to Rs 747.85. 

“With robust TCV (total contract value) signings and improving business visibility, we believe that Infosys would gradually catch up in revenue growth with TCS in FY2020E and in turn would narrow the valuation gap with TCS, going forward. Thus, we maintain our Buy rating on the stock with an unchanged price target (PT) of Rs 840,” said brokerage firm Sharekhan.


Stocks @fresh all-time high
As many as 13 stocks on the BSE500 hit their fresh all-time highs. The list includes stocks such as ICICI Lombard Life Insurance, Gillette India, Bajaj Finserv, PVR, SKF India, Pidilite, Honeywell Automation, Info Edge (India) and Infosys.


Sectoral scene
Sector-wise, BSE Auto as well as FMCG, Healthcare and Power indices rallied more than 1 per cent. However, BSE Telecom, Metal, Teck, IT and Consumer Durables weakened up to 2.84 per cent. 


Top Nifty gainers/losers
Wipro: With a rally of 8.13 per cent during the week, Wipro was the top gainer in the Nifty pack. Tata Motors (up 5.26 per cent), Bajaj Auto (up 5.12 per cent), Cipla (up 4.28 per cent) and ITC (up 3.80 per cent) brought up the rest of the list. 

Wipro is scheduled to announce its results on April 16. It's set to announce its largest buyback of Rs 12,000 crore ($1.7 billion) on the same day following Sebi's nod to the proposal. 

On the other hand, Indiabulls Housing Finance (down 8 per cent), Asian Paints (down 5.01 per cent) and Bharti Airtel (down 4.12 per cent) lost the game in the 50-share Nifty pack.

Asian Paints scrip fell after a fire at its paint manufacturing facility in Vishakhapatnam in Andhra Pradesh. The manufacturing operations have been affected since. 


DHFL skids
Shares of Dewan Housing Finance Corporation (DHFL) came down by over 3 per cent to Rs 167.10 on Friday after rating agency Brickwork Ratings India downgraded its secured NCDs and subordinated debt instruments. An ETNow report suggested that US-based large private equity (PE) player Lone Star Funds is eyeing a stake in the company. 


But SpicJet takes off
Shares of SpiceJet rallied over 10 per cent after the airline announced induction of new aircraft into its fleet. According to a BSE filing, the company will induct 16 Boeing 737-800 NG aircraft on dry lease in the next 10 days after regulatory approvals. 


Takeover buzz lifts Ruchi Soya
Shares of Ruchi Soya Industries climbed over 12 per cent to Rs 7.30 on April 12, from Rs 6.50 on April 5. An ET report suggested that Patanjali Ayurved’s proposed acquisition of Ruchi Soya has reached the final stages with the committee of creditors (CoC) scheduled to meet next Tuesday to clear the deal.

JM Financial has a buy call on Cholamandalam Financial Holdings (CFH) with a target price of Rs 620.

The current market price of Cholamandalam Financial Holdings is Rs 490.

Time period given by the brokerage is one year when Cholamandalam Financial Holdings price can reach the defined target. 


Investment rationale by the brokerage-

Provides a broader exposure to financials, similar to Bajaj Finserv: CFH is not just a pure lender. It has a more diversified play in the financial space as it offers exposure to both a consumer NBFC and general insurance. We believe CFH is a wealth creation candidate (similar to Bajaj Finserv) as both its businesses have attained a good scale (CIFC is the third largest asset finance company (AFC) in India and Chola MS is the seventh largest private general insurer) in underpenetrated and fast-growing verticals, both have championed their respective retail-oriented businesses, and there is tremendous scope to further increase scale and better the operations of these businesses.


Cholamandalam MS General Insurance - Efficient player in a highly lucrative general insurance industry: Indian general insurance has posted an 18 per cent CAGR in premiums during FY14-18, and outlook remains better as the industry is still significantly under-penetrated, urbanisation is rising and significant increase in asset ownership is expected. Moreover, given the low solvency and high underwriting losses of state-owned insurers who collectively have over a 50 per cent market share, we expect a structural shift towards stronger private players. Cholamandalam MS GIC with a strong JV partner, credible management, and controlled combined ratio will be a prime beneficiary. After a subdued FY19E due to investment losses (IL&FS Bonds) and higher claims in crop insurance, we build in GWDP / PAT CAGR of 15 per cent / 35 per cent during FY19E-21E, driven by growth recovery due to rationalisation of commission expense, shift in business mix away from Motor TPs, better claims ratio and normalisation in investment return. Capital infusion by both the partners is a possibility given that the solvency ratio is just above the minimum mandatory requirement.


Growth in value of investments + reduction in Holdco discount = market Cap expansion: CFH at the current price, quotes at a 41 per cent discount to the fair valuation of its investment companies, which is almost double the discount of Bajaj Finserv (quotes at 21 per cent discount at CMP). Unlike just an investment holding company, CFH has a majority holding and management control in both its businesses which should lead to a lower holding company discount. Given the 20 per cent PAT CAGR forecast during FY19E-21E and FY21E ROE of 19 per cent, we value CFH at Rs 620/Share on a SOTP basis giving it a 25 per cent holding company discount. KEY RISKS- Material slow down in commercial vehicle sales, abrupt rise in credit spreads, regulatory change in motor TP insurance segment, higher losses in crop / motor Insurance portfolio, catastrophe risk.

Whenever you see new kid on the IPO block, there will be positive excitement around it because merchant 
  
  
  bankers would also have their bit to do in terms of pushing it, said Hemang Jani, Senior Vice President, Sharekhan, in an interview with ETNOW. Edited excerpts: 

History is telling us not to worry about elections and move on, but street beleieves we will take a view only post the election verdict. Why is that?
What is playing in the minds of investors is the fact that for almost about 15 months or so, there has not been any meaningful appreciation in the portfolios, if you leave aside the top four to five index heavyweights. The performance of the broader market has not been that great. When for an extended period of 12 to 15 months, the portfolio gains are mediocre, that definitely weighs on decision making. 

Given the fact that even the earnings growth has not been that great and you have a major event coming up, that probably would put people into some kind of a tight spot. But if you look at the overall retail activity, particularly in March, mutual fund inflows have definitely improved. So, I agree that the participation has not been that great but given the fact that March has been a much better month and you have an event like election which would bring in a lot of volatility, retail participation from here on can increase. 


There are no signs of a breakthrough when it comes to the saga at Jet Airways. Now it seems like the talks have really drawn a blank. There is going to be another crucial board meeting that will extend today. What is the worst case scenario you can think for Jet Airways in light of this?
It is a sad episode for the Indian airline industry that one of the best performing airlines is going through this kind of a period. The fact that it is taking more time to get the funds and to bring in a new investor, is not boding well for the company because international operations have been halted and if they are not able to get the intervening relief, then there will be question marks on domestic operations also.

It is not a great news for the sector per se and let us hope that over the next few days they are able to at least get some fund infusion. If a very strong investor comes in, then the stock can start stabilising from here on.


The entire Nestle India royalty is not as bizarre a case like Jubilant Foodworks and a royalty here is only justifiable, but would it go down well with minority shareholders if the quantum is a little too high?
This royalty issue has always been there for many of the MNC companies and whenever there is some increase or a new proposal, there is going to be a lot of media hype around it and there can be a bit of a negative knee-jerk reaction. But the companies are very strong and they enjoy a brand and product franchise. I do not think the market is going to be too much worried about it and in case of Nestle, last year has been good. They have been able to win the market share. The entire controversy around Maggi has died down. and the company has started really doing pretty well on the volumes front. I do not think we should read too much negatively into this royalty issue at this point of time.


Suddenly there is a lot of interest in the insurance space. Is this a pure rotation, a migration of flows not by choice but by compulsion?
It is possible that some part of the money which is meant for investments in the financial services space could move into the insurance space. For the last couple of months, we have seen major deals happening over there. In ICICI Pru, we could see a big investor coming in and from there the stock has recovered. 

The larger issue for the insurance company has been that a company like Prudential ICICI which has a larger dependence on the ULIP related products. There is a sense that dependence will go down and overall in the pure term plan segment per se, the companies are delivering a very healthy growth. A combination of this new money coming in and the fact that with the ULIP related issues have actually played out, people are becoming a little more positive and partly also because some of the companies could be included in some of the indices where the rebalancing is happening will also bring in an element of new flows. 

A combination of these factors are playing out and we continue to be positive on that sector. Our preferred stock is definitely Bajaj Finserv which has general insurance as well as life insurance and is quoting at a discount of about 12% to 15% to HDFC Life and ICICI Pru.


It is good to see that the IPO market is thriving again. The subscription numbers were absolutely amazing. What is so unique about Polycab India? Why is there was so much interest in a business which is more a B2B and less a B2C business?
The product range and the business model of Polycab is pretty similar to some of the names like Havells or V-Guard or KI Industries, Crompton etc. with consumer products a decent amount of volume growth of about 12 to 15%. 

Polycab could be one of the companies that will fit into that particular segment. They have a very decent market share and they are also moving into those newer categories where growth could be in excess of about 12-15%. The market at this point of time likes to move into these kind of niche companies with a decent amount of brand volume growth in excess of 10%. We have not had any major IPO pipeline because of the weak sentiment in the broader market. Whenever you see new kid on the block, there will be positive excitement around it because merchant bankers would also have their bit to do in terms of pushing it. It could be a decent company from investor perspective.


Who is buying Tata Motors?
If you look at the last monthly numbers particularly from the markets like US, UK and some of the other markets, the data has shown a marked improvement. Also, after the S&P downgrades, the management came out and gave a positive guidance in terms of their overall growth and the sense one is getting is that after such a huge underperformance, finally the stock has started catching up on the domestic market because of the product rollouts that they have had, met with some amount of success. 

I think some people might be taking a call that the worst is over in terms of operational performance and price performance and risk rewards looks better but it has been the most difficult stock to track in terms of what is really happening. We have always had a neutral stance on the stock for quite some time and we continue to remain that way.


What is your view on Dr Reddy’s? Their Bachupally unit, which accounts for 45% of the US revenues, has got an EIR by the USFDA. Would you be willing to buy DRL just yet?
Yes, this development is quite positive because the lifting of the warning letter or this EIR that they have got for Bachupally is definitely important. What is more important is that within a very short timeframe, they could actually bring in this particular EIR and overall, most of the pharma companies the US business is stabilising and on a quarter-on-quarter basis, there has been a decent amount of growth with margin and outlook continuing to be good. 

Some of these stocks present a good investment opportunity and we expect even DRL to do well from a 12-month perspective at current price point.

Want to beat the Nifty 50’s returns over the next 12 months? Go contrarian. That’s what the one-year forward Bloomberg consensus target prices of Nifty 50 companies suggest.

According to the consensus, the Nifty will gain 7.2 per cent in a year — is one of the highest anticipated return among major global markets. The quirky part, however, is the stocks that are expected to gain more than 10 per cent have been underperformers over the past six months. These include ONGC, Hindalco, Mahindra & Mahindra, Larsen & Toubro (L&T), and Zee Entertainment. In addition, the stocks including Reliance Industries, UltraTech, Kotak Mahindra Bank, and Bajaj Finserv, which have largely driven the current rally, seem to have reached full potential.




Barring L&T, the other four stocks, which are likely to offer the highest upsides, failed to generate returns in the past six months while the Nifty rose 11.2 per cent during the same period. ONGC has the highest likely upside of 28 per cent in the next 12 months.

Among the index heavyweights, HDFC Bank, ITC, Hindustan Unilever and ICICI, which together have 24 per cent weight in the Nifty, offer an upside of 10.4-12.6 per cent over the next one year.

The top 10 stocks, which have 20 per cent weight in the Nifty, earned 19.7 per cent return in the past six months pushing the index to record levels. Among them, eight stocks now trade above their consensus target prices. Wipro has the maximum downside of 10 per cent followed by Bajaj Auto (8.6 per cent downside) and Bajaj Finserv (10.1 per cent downside) over the next 12 months.

Mumbai: RBL Bank posted a 39 per cent profit growth in the March quarter on the back of robust credit growth and other income, and also laid out plans to raise Rs 3,500 crore in capital as it looks to accelerate corporate lending.

The private sector lender’s earnings grew to Rs 247 crore from Rs 178 crore, a year ago, while their consolidated loan book grew 35 per cent to Rs 54,000 crore in this period.

Net Interest Income (NII), the difference between what it earned and what it paid for funds, increased 44 per cent to Rs 2,540 crore. RBL’s shares fell 0.5 per cent to Rs 677.



“Our retail lending portfolio is growing faster, but our corporate portfolio has also seen a healthy growth,’’ said Vishwavir Ahuja, MD and CEO, RBL. “In our experience, large corporate loans have seen lesser stress than medium and small corporates. “We would be looking to grow our wholesale book by 20 per cent over the next year by targeting a 25 per cent growth in advances to large corporates.”

Partnership with technology players such as CreditVidya for loan underwriting and fintech-NBFC Bajaj Finserv helped the lender register healthy growth in its micro finance and credit card businesses with 41 per cent and 135 per cent yearly growth respectively.

“We have now 17 lakh credit card holders of which 10 lakh have been through our partnership with Bajaj Finserv,” Ahuja said.

Stress in its agri-related assets due to farm loan waivers and tractor sale slowdown grew. Gross NPA rate remained stable at 1.38 per cent down from 1.40 per cent in March quarter last year. Provision Coverage Ratio (PCR) in correspondence also rose to 65 per cent from 57.6 per cent in this period.

“There has been some uptick in standard provisioning as we took additional provisions due to some stress in the agri portfolio. The last leg of demonetisation related provisioning which was spread over last year has also now been completed,” said Ahuja.

Though the bank’s capital adequacy ratio remained above regulatory needs at 13.4 per cent, it would raise around Rs 3,500 crore through share sales in the next 18 months.

“We have adequate capital for at least the next one year. Over the next 18 months depending on shareholder approval and capital requirement, we’ll decide equity fund raise, modality timing and actual capital to be raised for which the upper limit is Rs 3,500 crore,” Ahuja said.

CASA ratio was at 25 per cent with the bank expressing desire to increase it to 30 per cent over the next three years. Its fee income, a key factor that investors watch in a bank as to how it earns without putting much capital, rose 43 per cent to Rs 388 crore.
